metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Respondent, Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Ltd., assessed under Hyderabad Income-tax Act for years 1357-F, 1358-F, 1359-F with depreciation on written down value per cl. c of s. 125.
Erstwhile State of Hyderabad merged in Union of India on January 26, 1950, becoming Part B State.
Finance Act, 1950, s.13 repealed taxation laws in Part B States; s.3 extended Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 to whole of India except Jammu & Kashmir.

Central Government made Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 vide notification December 2, 1950; para 2 required taking into account all depreciation actually allowed under Part B State laws in computing aggregate depreciation and WDV under s.10(2)(vi) proviso (c) and s.10(5)(b) of Indian IT Act.

For assessment year 1951-52 (account year ending June 30, 1950), respondent assessed under Indian IT Act read with Part B States (Taxation Concessions) Order, 1950; claimed depreciation Rs.8,12,244 based on actual cost minus depreciation actually allowed under Hyderabad Act per para 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order.
ITO by order November 30, 1951 disallowed claim, took WDV from 1359-F proceedings, interpreting 'allowed' as 'considered only'.
AAC Hyderabad by order May 23, 1952 upheld ITO.
ITAT Bombay Bench by order December 12, 1952 allowed respondent's appeal, held entitled to actual cost minus depreciation actually allowed under Hyderabad Act per para 2.
Appellant applied to ITAT for reference u/s 66(1) Indian IT Act.

Central Govt added Explanation to para 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order u/s 60A Indian IT Act on March 9, 1953: 'all depreciation actually allowed' means aggregate allowance taken into account in computing WDV under Part B State laws.
ITAT stated case on question: Whether assessee entitled to depreciation on WDV at 1359-F or actual cost minus depreciation granted under Hyderabad Act.
Hyderabad High Court by order February 16, 1954 held 1953 Explanation void (ultra vires s.60A), answered question for respondent.
Appellant obtained certificate u/s 66A(2) Indian IT Act, filed appeal.
Central Govt added identical Explanation to para 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order u/s 12 Finance Act, 1950 vide S.O. 1139 dated May 8, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether in making assessment for 1951-52 under Indian IT Act, assessee entitled to depreciation on WDV computed at time of 1359-F assessment or on actual cost minus depreciation allowances granted under Hyderabad IT Act.
Whether 1956 notification adding Explanation to para 2 of Removal of Difficulties Order valid under s.12 Finance Act 1950, or ultra vires.
Whether 1956 notification has retrospective effect applying to 1951-52 assessment.
Whether 1956 notification contravenes Art.14 of Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: 1956 notification valid under s.12 Finance Act 1950, removes difficulty in giving effect to extended provisions; not ultra vires.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Finance Act 1950 s.12; Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. State of MP

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification has retrospective effect, deems expression 'always' to have meant aggregate depreciation in WDV computation.
No violation of Art.14 as assessees in different Part B States not similarly situated.

respondent_arguments.text: No difficulty arose under s.12 Finance Act as para 2 Removal of Difficulties Order already resolved initial issues; notification ultra vires.
Notification cannot have retrospective effect; law for 1951-52 is as on April 28, 1951 when Finance Act 1951 came into force.
Notification violates Art.14 by discriminating between assessees in different Part B State areas based on prior laws.

court_reasoning.text: Difficulty existed in applying s.10(5)(b) to Part B States as prior depreciation not under Indian IT Act or repealed Act; para 2 Removal Order addressed but led to anomaly of higher depreciation post-1950 than prior; 1956 Explanation removes this disharmony.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Basic scheme of depreciation decreases yearly on WDV; anomaly against scheme.

court_reasoning.text: S.12 empowers Central Govt to determine difficulty and remove it; executive determination valid per precedent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not unconstitutional to leave details to executive.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation deems 'always' meant aggregate in WDV; s.12 power includes retrospective removal of difficulty from inception.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies to all assessments where para 2 operates, including 1951-52.

court_reasoning.text: Assessees in different Part B areas not similarly situated due to varying prior laws; treating differently not discriminatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies uniformly to those under para 2.

holdings.text: 1956 notification valid under s.12 Finance Act 1950, not ultra vires, applies retrospectively to 1951-52 assessment; depreciation on basis of WDV per aggregate depreciation under prior law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. The State of Madhya Pradesh Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature may leave details of taxation laws to executive.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs depreciation computation on WDV; basis for reference.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended IT Act to Part B States, repealed prior laws, empowered Removal of Difficulties Order.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior law under which respondent assessed; depreciation basis disputed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Tested for discrimination; held not violated.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order dated February 16, 1954 set aside; question answered in favour of appellant (Commissioner).
outcome.relief_granted: Question answered for appellant: depreciation not on actual cost minus actually allowed, but per Explanation (aggregate in WDV).

key_quotes.text: "If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of any of the Acts, rules or orders extended by section 3 or section 11 to any State or merged territory, the Central Government may by order, make such provision, or give such direction, as appears to it to be necessary for removing the difficulty."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.12 Finance Act 1950, basis for upholding notification.

key_quotes.text: "the true scope and effect of s. 12 seems to be that it is for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in the section has arisen and then to make such order, or give such direction, as appears to it to be necessary to remove the difficulty."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "In the matter of depreciation allowance, the assessee in the three areas in the example given by him do not stand on the same footing they are not situated alike so as to be entitled to be treated alike."
key_quotes.speaker: court
